hints.content:
We know the function increases after it intersects its midline at $(-1,2)$. Therefore, it has a maximum point *a quarter of a period* to the right and *an amplitude* up (see drawing of a general wave function).

$\qquad$![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/618d937cd2fd1e45c8135fff5eccf81dba7654ca.png)

The period of the function is $10$, so the $x$-coordinate of the maximum point is $-1+\dfrac{10}{4}=1.5$.

The amplitude of the function is $3$, so the $y$-coordinate of the maximum point is $2+3=5$.

- The function intersects its midline at $(-1,2)$.


- The function has a maximum point at $(1.5,5)$.


- The resulting graph looks as follows:

$\qquad$![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/8652d283583a17d9988bbe6f70f3baebaf59dfd7.png)

question.content:
A trigonometric function has the following features:

- Its period is $10$ units


- Its amplitude is $3$ units


- It intersects its midline at $(-1,2)$ and then increases

**Graph the function in the interactive widget.**

$$[[☃ grapher 1]]

hints.content:
We know the function increases after it intersects its midline at $(-6,-1.5)$. Therefore, it has a maximum point *a quarter of a period* to the right and *an amplitude* up (see drawing of a general wave function).

$\qquad$![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/618d937cd2fd1e45c8135fff5eccf81dba7654ca.png)

The period of the function is $6$, so the $x$-coordinate of the maximum point is $-6+\dfrac{6}{4}=-4.5$.

The amplitude of the function is $7$, so the $y$-coordinate of the maximum point is $-1.5+7=5.5$.

- The function intersects its midline at $(-6,-1.5)$.


- The function has a maximum point at $(-4.5,5.5)$.


- The resulting graph looks as follows:

$\qquad$![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6cee6a1c29631f1a7eb9b6125f318a7f08c51694.png)

question.content:

hints.content:
We know the function increases after it intersects its midline at $(4.5,-7)$. Therefore, it has a maximum point *a quarter of a period* to the right and *an amplitude* up (see drawing of a general wave function).

$\qquad$![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/618d937cd2fd1e45c8135fff5eccf81dba7654ca.png)

The period of the function is $14$, so the $x$-coordinate of the maximum point is $4.5+\dfrac{14}{4}=8$.

The amplitude of the function is $2.5$, so the $y$-coordinate of the maximum point is $-7+2.5=-4.5$.

- The function intersects its midline at $(4.5,-7)$.


- The function has a maximum point at $(8,-4.5)$.

question.content:
A trigonometric function has the following features:

- Its amplitude is $2.5$ units

hints.content:
We know the function decreases after it intersects its midline at $(3,-3)$. Therefore, it has a minimum point *a quarter of a period* to the right and *an amplitude* down (see drawing of a general wave function).

$\qquad$![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/618d937cd2fd1e45c8135fff5eccf81dba7654ca.png)

The period of the function is $8$, so the $x$-coordinate of the minimum point is $3+\dfrac{8}{4}=5$.

The amplitude of the function is $5.5$, so the $y$-coordinate of the minimum point is $-3-5.5=-8.5$.

- The function intersects its midline at $(3,-3)$.


- The function has a minimum point at $(5,-8.5)$.


- The resulting graph looks as follows:

The period of the function is $16$, so the $x$-coordinate of the minimum point is $-2+\dfrac{16}{4}=2$.

A trigonometric function has the following features:

- Its amplitude is $6$ units


- It intersects its midline at $(-2,3.5)$ and then decreases

$$[[☃ grapher 1]]

hints.content:
We know the function increases after it intersects its midline at $\left(\dfrac{\pi}{2},5\right)$. Therefore, it has a maximum point *a quarter of a period* to the right and *an amplitude* up (see drawing of a general wave function).

$\qquad$![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/618d937cd2fd1e45c8135fff5eccf81dba7654ca.png)

The period of the function is $\pi$, so the $x$-coordinate of the maximum point is $\dfrac{\pi}{2}+\dfrac{\pi}{4}=\dfrac{3}{4}\pi$.

The amplitude of the function is $4$, so the $y$-coordinate of the maximum point is $5+4=9$.

- The function intersects its midline at $\left(\dfrac{\pi}{2},5\right)$.


- The function has a maximum point at $\left(\dfrac{3}{4}\pi,9\right)$.


- The resulting graph looks as follows:

$\qquad$![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5a6ae7becca52e56012383afb6ed64bac6fc5d05.png)

question.content:
A trigonometric function has the following features:

- Its period is $\pi$ units


- Its amplitude is $4$ units


- It intersects its midline at $\left(\dfrac{\pi}{2},5\right)$ and then increases

**Graph the function in the interactive widget.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
We know the function increases after it intersects its midline at $\left(-\dfrac{5}{2}\pi,-6.5\right)$. Therefore, it has a maximum point *a quarter of a period* to the right and *an amplitude* up (see drawing of a general wave function).

$\qquad$![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/618d937cd2fd1e45c8135fff5eccf81dba7654ca.png)

The period of the function is $4\pi$, so the $x$-coordinate of the maximum point is $-\dfrac{5}{2}\pi+\dfrac{4\pi}{4}=-\dfrac{3}{2}\pi$.

The amplitude of the function is $1$, so the $y$-coordinate of the maximum point is $-6.5+1=-5.5$.

- The function intersects its midline at $\left(-\dfrac{5}{2}\pi,-6.5\right)$.


- The function has a maximum point at $\left(-\dfrac{3}{2}\pi,-5.5\right)$.


- The resulting graph looks as follows:

$\qquad$![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2054b67a5a448f3edff70aa0655a0db7e65fed7a.png)

question.content:
A trigonometric function has the following features:

- Its period is $4\pi$ units


- Its amplitude is $1$ unit


- It intersects its midline at $\left(-\dfrac{5}{2}\pi,-6.5\right)$ and then increases

**Graph the function in the interactive widget.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
We know the function decreases after it intersects its midline at $\left(2\pi,1\right)$. Therefore, it has a minmum point *a quarter of a period* to the right and *an amplitude* down (see drawing of a general wave function).

$\qquad$![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/618d937cd2fd1e45c8135fff5eccf81dba7654ca.png)

The period of the function is $3\pi$, so the $x$-coordinate of the minimum point is $2\pi+\dfrac{3\pi}{4}=\dfrac{11}{4}\pi$.

The amplitude of the function is $8$, so the $y$-coordinate of the minimum point is $1-8=-7$.

- The function intersects its midline at $\left(2\pi,1\right)$.


- The function has a minimum point at $\left(\dfrac{11}{4}\pi,-7\right)$.


- The resulting graph looks as follows:

$\qquad$![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/bd5947d93dd5b6c2d5dd4e1b3c4884bf5aaf854d.png)

$\qquad$![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/618d937cd2fd1e45c8135fff5eccf81dba7654ca.png)

The period of the function is $2\pi$, so the $x$-coordinate of the minimum point is $-\dfrac{5}{4}\pi+\dfrac{2\pi}{4}=-\dfrac{3}{4}\pi$.

The amplitude of the function is $6.5$, so the $y$-coordinate of the minimum point is $3-6.5=-3.5$.

- The function intersects its midline at $\left(-\dfrac{5}{4}\pi,3\right)$.

question.content:
A trigonometric function has the following features:

- Its period is $2\pi$ units


- Its amplitude is $6.5$ units


- It intersects its midline at $\left(-\dfrac{5}{4}\pi,3\right)$ and then decreases

**Graph the function in the interactive widget.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
We know the function decreases after it intersects its midline at $\left(\dfrac{3}{4}\pi,-2\right)$. Therefore, it has a minmum point *a quarter of a period* to the right and *an amplitude* down (see drawing of a general wave function).

$\qquad$![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/618d937cd2fd1e45c8135fff5eccf81dba7654ca.png)

The period of the function is $5\pi$, so the $x$-coordinate of the minimum point is $\dfrac{3}{4}\pi+\dfrac{5\pi}{4}=2\pi$.

The amplitude of the function is $5$, so the $y$-coordinate of the minimum point is $-2-5=-7$.

- The function intersects its midline at $\left(\dfrac{3}{4}\pi,-2\right)$.


- The function has a minimum point at $\left(2\pi,-7\right)$.


- The resulting graph looks as follows:

$\qquad$![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/338b9cd702235599c2d09d78cc7b83d0b9ee482e.png)

question.content:
A trigonometric function has the following features:

- Its period is $5\pi$ units


- Its amplitude is $5$ units


- It intersects its midline at $\left(\dfrac{3}{4}\pi,-2\right)$ and then decreases

**Graph the function in the interactive widget.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
We will use the given information to find the values of all the coefficients in the form $f(x)=\red{a}\sin(\blue{b}x+\green{c})+\purple{d}$.

$\red{a}=\red{2}$ because the amplitude is equal to $|\red{a}|$ and $a>0$.

The equation $\dfrac{\pi}{2}=\dfrac{2\pi}{\blue{b}}$ holds because the period is equal to $\dfrac{2\pi}{|\blue{b}|}$ and $b>0$. Let's solve this equation:

$\qquad \begin{align} \dfrac{\pi}{2}&=\dfrac{2\pi}{b}\\\\
\dfrac{\pi}{\cancel2}\cdot\cancel2b&=\dfrac{2\pi}{\cancel b}\cdot2\cancel b\\\\
\pi\cdot b&=4\pi\\
\blue{b}&=\blue{4}\end{align}$

The function has a *sine* expression, so it intersects its midline when $bx+\green{c}=0$. We know that this happens when $x=1$, and we already know that $b=4$. We can plug these values into the equation to find $\green{c}$.

$\qquad \begin{align} b\cdot x+c&=0\\4\cdot1+c&=0\\
\green{c}&=\green{-4}\\\\\end{align}$

$\purple{d}=\purple{3}$ because the midline equation is $y=\purple{d}$.

Now we have a complete formula for $f(x)$:

$\qquad f(x)=\red{2}\sin(\blue{4}x\green{-4})+\purple{3}$

question.content:
$f$ is a trigonometric function of the form $f(x)=a\sin(bx+c)+d$. It has the following features:

- Its amplitude is $2$ units


- Its period is $\dfrac{\pi}{2}$ units


- It intersects its midline at $(1,3)$


- $a>0$ and $b>0$

**Find a formula for $f(x)$.**

$\qquad f(x)=$ [[☃ expression 1]]

hints.content:
We will use the given information to find the values of all the coefficients in the form $g(x)=\red{a}\sin(\blue{b}x+\green{c})+\purple{d}$.

$\red{a}=\red{10}$ because the amplitude is equal to $|\red{a}|$ and $a>0$.

The equation $2=\dfrac{2\pi}{\blue{b}}$ holds because the period is equal to $\dfrac{2\pi}{|\blue{b}|}$ and $b>0$. Let's solve this equation:

$\qquad \begin{align} 2&=\dfrac{2\pi}{b}\\\\
2 b&=2\pi\\
\blue{b}&=\blue{\pi}\end{align}$

The function has a *sine* expression, so it intersects its midline when $bx+\green{c}=0$. We know that this happens when $x=-5$, and we already know that $b=\pi$. We can plug these values into the equation to find $\green{c}$.

$\qquad \begin{align} b\cdot x+c&=0\\
\pi\cdot(-5)+c&=0\\
\green{c}&=\green{5\pi}\\\\\end{align}$

$\purple{d}=\purple{-4}$ because the midline equation is $y=\purple{d}$.

Now we have a complete formula for $g(x)$:

$\qquad g(x)=\red{10}\sin(\blue{\pi}x+\green{5\pi})\purple{-4}$

question.content:
$g$ is a trigonometric function of the form $g(x)=a\sin(bx+c)+d$. It has the following features:

- Its amplitude is $10$ units


- Its period is $2$ units


- It intersects its midline at $(-5,-4)$


- $a>0$ and $b>0$

**Find a formula for $g(x)$.**

$\qquad g(x)=$ [[☃ expression 1]]

hints.content:
We will use the given information to find the values of all the coefficients in the form $h(x)=\red{a}\sin(\blue{b}x+\green{c})+\purple{d}$.

$\red{a}=\red{4.5}$ because the amplitude is equal to $|\red{a}|$ and $a>0$.

The equation $\pi=\dfrac{2\pi}{\blue{b}}$ holds because the period is equal to $\dfrac{2\pi}{|\blue{b}|}$ and $b>0$. Let's solve this equation:

$\qquad \begin{align} \pi&=\dfrac{2\pi}{b}\\\\
\pi\cdot b&=2\pi\\
\blue{b}&=\blue{2}\end{align}$

The function has a *sine* expression, so it intersects its midline when $bx+\green{c}=0$. We know that this happens when $x=-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$, and we already know that $b=2$. We can plug these values into the equation to find $\green{c}$.

$\qquad \begin{align} b\cdot x+c&=0\\
2\cdot\left(-\dfrac{\pi}{2}\right)+c&=0\\
\green{c}&=\green{\pi}\\\\\end{align}$

$\purple{d}=\purple{7}$ because the midline equation is $y=\purple{d}$.

Now we have a complete formula for $h(x)$:

$\qquad h(x)=\red{4.5}\sin(\blue{2}x+\green{\pi})\purple{+7}$

question.content:
$h$ is a trigonometric function of the form $h(x)=a\sin(bx+c)+d$. It has the following features:

- Its amplitude is $4.5$ units


- Its period is $\pi$ units


- It intersects its midline at $\left(-\dfrac{\pi}{2},7\right)$


- $a>0$ and $b>0$

**Find a formula for $h(x)$.**

$\qquad h(x)=$ [[☃ expression 1]]

hints.content:
We will use the given information to find the values of all the coefficients in the form $f(x)=\red{a}\sin(\blue{b}x+\green{c})+\purple{d}$.

$\red{a}=\red{7}$ because the amplitude is equal to $|\red{a}|$ and $a>0$.

The equation $4\pi=\dfrac{2\pi}{\blue{b}}$ holds because the period is equal to $\dfrac{2\pi}{|\blue{b}|}$ and $b>0$. Let's solve this equation:

$\qquad \begin{align} 4\pi&=\dfrac{2\pi}{b}\\\\
4\pi\cdot b&=2\pi\\
\blue{b}&=\blue{0.5}\end{align}$

The function has a *sine* expression, so it intersects its midline when $bx+\green{c}=0$. We know that this happens when $x=3.5$, and we already know that $b=0.5$. We can plug these values into the equation to find $\green{c}$.

$\qquad \begin{align} b\cdot x+c&=0\\
0.5\cdot3.5+c&=0\\
\green{c}&=\green{-1.75}\\\\\end{align}$

$\purple{d}=\purple{-5.5}$ because the midline equation is $y=\purple{d}$.

Now we have a complete formula for $f(x)$:

$\qquad f(x)=\red{7}\sin(\blue{0.5}x\green{-1.75})\purple{-5.5}$

question.content:
$f$ is a trigonometric function of the form $f(x)=a\sin(bx+c)+d$. It has the following features:

- Its amplitude is $7$ units


- Its period is $4\pi$ units


- It intersects its midline at $(3.5,-5.5)$

hints.content:
We will use the given information to find the values of all the coefficients in the form $g(x)=\red{a}\sin(\blue{b}x+\green{c})+\purple{d}$.

$\red{a}=\red{12.5}$ because the amplitude is equal to $|\red{a}|$ and $a>0$.

The equation $3=\dfrac{2\pi}{\blue{b}}$ holds because the period is equal to $\dfrac{2\pi}{|\blue{b}|}$ and $b>0$. Let's solve this equation:

$\qquad \begin{align} 3&=\dfrac{2\pi}{b}\\\\
3b&=2\pi\\
\blue{b}&=\blue{\dfrac{2}{3}\pi}\end{align}$

The function has a *sine* expression, so it intersects its midline when $bx+\green{c}=0$. We know that this happens when $x=9$, and we already know that $b=\dfrac{2}{3}\pi$. We can plug these values into the equation to find $\green{c}$.

$\qquad \begin{align} b\cdot x+c&=0\\
\dfrac{2}{3}\pi\cdot 9+c&=0\\
\green{c}&=\green{-6\pi}\\\\\end{align}$

$\purple{d}=\purple{10}$ because the midline equation is $y=\purple{d}$.

Now we have a complete formula for $g(x)$:

$\qquad g(x)=\red{12.5}\sin\left(\blue{\dfrac{2}{3}\pi}x\green{-6\pi}\right)\purple{+10}$

question.content:
$g$ is a trigonometric function of the form $g(x)=a\sin(bx+c)+d$. It has the following features:

- Its amplitude is $12.5$ units


- Its period is $3$ units


- It intersects its midline at $(9,10)$


- $a>0$ and $b>0$

**Find a formula for $g(x)$.**

$\qquad g(x)=$ [[☃ expression 1]]

hints.content:
We will use the given information to find the values of all the coefficients in the form $h(x)=\red{a}\sin(\blue{b}x+\green{c})+\purple{d}$.

$\red{a}=\red{-3}$ because the amplitude is equal to $|\red{a}|$ and $a<0$.

The equation $\dfrac{3}{2}\pi=\dfrac{2\pi}{\blue{b}}$ holds because the period is equal to $\dfrac{2\pi}{|\blue{b}|}$ and $b>0$. Let's solve this equation:

$\qquad \begin{align} \dfrac{3}{2}\pi&=\dfrac{2\pi}{b}\\\\
\dfrac{3}{\cancel2}\pi\cdot\cancel2b&=\dfrac{2\pi}{\cancel b}\cdot2\cancel{b}\\\\
3\pi b&=4\pi\\
\blue{b}&=\blue{\dfrac{4}{3}}\end{align}$

The function has a *sine* expression, so it intersects its midline when $bx+\green{c}=0$. We know that this happens when $x=\dfrac{3}2{}\pi$, and we already know that $b=\dfrac{4}{3}$. We can plug these values into the equation to find $\green{c}$.

$\qquad \begin{align} b\cdot x+c&=0\\
\dfrac{4}{3}\cdot \dfrac{3}{2}\pi+c&=0\\
\green{c}&=\green{-2\pi}\\\\\end{align}$

$\purple{d}=\purple{-6}$ because the midline equation is $y=\purple{d}$.

Now we have a complete formula for $h(x)$:

$\qquad h(x)=\red{-3}\sin\left(\blue{\dfrac{4}{3}}x\green{-2\pi}\right)\purple{-6}$

question.content:
$h$ is a trigonometric function of the form $h(x)=a\sin(bx+c)+d$. It has the following features:

- Its amplitude is $3$ units


- Its period is $\dfrac{3}{2}\pi$ units

- $a<0$ and $b>0$

hints.content:
We will use the given information to find the values of all the coefficients in the form $f(x)=\red{a}\sin(\blue{b}x+\green{c})+\purple{d}$.

$\red{a}=\red{-8.5}$ because the amplitude is equal to $|\red{a}|$ and $a<0$.

The equation $3\pi=\dfrac{2\pi}{\blue{b}}$ holds because the period is equal to $\dfrac{2\pi}{|\blue{b}|}$ and $b>0$. Let's solve this equation:

$\qquad \begin{align} 3\pi&=\dfrac{2\pi}{b}\\\\
3\pi b&=2\pi\\
\blue{b}&=\blue{\dfrac{2}{3}}\end{align}$

The function has a *sine* expression, so it intersects its midline when $bx+\green{c}=0$. We know that this happens when $x=-3.75$, and we already know that $b=\dfrac{2}{3}$. We can plug these values into the equation to find $\green{c}$.

$\qquad \begin{align} b\cdot x+c&=0\\
\dfrac{2}{3}\cdot (-3.75)+c&=0\\
\green{c}&=\green{2.5}\\\\\end{align}$

$\purple{d}=\purple{9.5}$ because the midline equation is $y=\purple{d}$.

Now we have a complete formula for $f(x)$:

$\qquad f(x)=\red{-8.5}\sin\left(\blue{\dfrac{2}{3}}x\green{+2.5}\right)\purple{+9.5}$

question.content:
$f$ is a trigonometric function of the form $f(x)=a\sin(bx+c)+d$. It has the following features:

- Its amplitude is $8.5$ units


- Its period is $3\pi$ units


- It intersects its midline at $(-3.75,9.5)$


- $a<0$ and $b>0$

**Find a formula for $f(x)$.**

$\qquad f(x)=$ [[☃ expression 1]]

hints.content:
We will use the given information to find the values of all the coefficients in the form $g(x)=\red{a}\sin(\blue{b}x+\green{c})+\purple{d}$.

$\red{a}=\red{-5}$ because the amplitude is equal to $|\red{a}|$ and $a<0$.

The equation $5=\dfrac{2\pi}{\blue{b}}$ holds because the period is equal to $\dfrac{2\pi}{|\blue{b}|}$ and $b>0$. Let's solve this equation:

$\qquad \begin{align} 5&=\dfrac{2\pi}{b}\\\\
5 b&=2\pi\\
\blue{b}&=\blue{\dfrac{2}{5}\pi}\end{align}$

The function has a *sine* expression, so it intersects its midline when $bx+\green{c}=0$. We know that this happens when $x=-2$, and we already know that $b=\dfrac{2}{5}\pi$. We can plug these values into the equation to find $\green{c}$.

$\qquad \begin{align} b\cdot x+c&=0\\
\dfrac{2}{5}\pi\cdot (-2)+c&=0\\
\green{c}&=\green{\dfrac{4}{5}\pi}\\\\\end{align}$

$\purple{d}=\purple{-8}$ because the midline equation is $y=\purple{d}$.

Now we have a complete formula for $g(x)$:

$\qquad g(x)=\red{-5}\sin\left(\blue{\dfrac{2}{5}\pi}x\green{+\dfrac{4}{5}\pi}\right)\purple{-8}$

question.content:
$g$ is a trigonometric function of the form $g(x)=a\sin(bx+c)+d$. It has the following features:

- Its amplitude is $5$ units


- Its period is $5$ units


- It intersects its midline at $(-2,-8)$


- $a<0$ and $b>0$

**Find a formula for $g(x)$.**

$\qquad g(x)=$ [[☃ expression 1]]

hints.content:
We will use the given information to find the values of all the coefficients in the form $h(x)=\red{a}\sin(\blue{b}x+\green{c})+\purple{d}$.

$\red{a}=\red{-13}$ because the amplitude is equal to $|\red{a}|$ and $a<0$.

The equation $\dfrac{\pi}{3}=\dfrac{2\pi}{\blue{b}}$ holds because the period is equal to $\dfrac{2\pi}{|\blue{b}|}$ and $b>0$. Let's solve this equation:

$\qquad \begin{align} \dfrac{\pi}{3}&=\dfrac{2\pi}{b}\\\\
\dfrac{\pi}{\cancel3}\cdot\cancel3b&=\dfrac{2\pi}{\cancel{b}}\cdot3\cancel{b}\\\\
\pi b&=6\pi\\
\blue{b}&=\blue{6}\end{align}$

The function has a *sine* expression, so it intersects its midline when $bx+\green{c}=0$. We know that this happens when $x=3\pi$, and we already know that $b=6$. We can plug these values into the equation to find $\green{c}$.

$\qquad \begin{align} b\cdot x+c&=0\\
6\cdot3\pi+c&=0\\
\green{c}&=\green{-18\pi}\\\\\end{align}$

$\purple{d}=\purple{0}$ because the midline equation is $y=\purple{d}$.

Now we have a complete formula for $h(x)$:

$\qquad h(x)=\red{-13}\sin\left(\blue{6}x\green{-18\pi}\right)$

question.content:
$h$ is a trigonometric function of the form $h(x)=a\sin(bx+c)+d$. It has the following features:

- Its amplitude is $13$ units


- Its period is $\dfrac{\pi}{3}$ units


- It intersects its midline at $(3\pi,0)$


- $a<0$ and $b>0$

**Find a formula for $h(x)$.**

$\qquad h(x)=$ [[☃ expression 1]]

hints.content:
We will use the given information to find the values of all the coefficients in the form $f(x)=\red{a}\sin(\blue{b}x+\green{c})+\purple{d}$.

$\red{a}=\red{-1}$ because the amplitude is equal to $|\red{a}|$ and $a<0$.

The equation $\dfrac{4}{5}\pi=\dfrac{2\pi}{\blue{b}}$ holds because the period is equal to $\dfrac{2\pi}{|\blue{b}|}$ and $b>0$. Let's solve this equation:

$\qquad \begin{align} \dfrac{4}{5}\pi&=\dfrac{2\pi}{b}\\\\
\dfrac{4}{\cancel5}\pi\cdot\cancel5b&=\dfrac{2\pi}{\cancel{b}}\cdot5\cancel{b}\\\\
4\pi b&=10\pi\\
\blue{b}&=\blue{2.5}\end{align}$

The function has a *sine* expression, so it intersects its midline when $bx+\green{c}=0$. We know that this happens when $x=-6$, and we already know that $b=2.5$. We can plug these values into the equation to find $\green{c}$.

$\qquad \begin{align} b\cdot x+c&=0\\
2.5\cdot(-6)+c&=0\\
\green{c}&=\green{15}\\\\\end{align}$

$\purple{d}=\purple{15}$ because the midline equation is $y=\purple{d}$.

Now we have a complete formula for $f(x)$:

$\qquad f(x)=\red{-}\sin\left(\blue{2.5}x\green{+15}\right)\purple{+15}$

question.content:
$f$ is a trigonometric function of the form $f(x)=a\sin(bx+c)+d$. It has the following features:

- Its amplitude is $1$ unit


- Its period is $\dfrac{4}{5}\pi$ units


- It intersects its midline at $(-6,15)$


- $a<0$ and $b>0$

**Find a formula for $f(x)$.**

$\qquad f(x)=$ [[☃ expression 1]]
